Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope for Cross-Disciplinary Research, Education and Community Outreach
Award.AbstractNarration:
1337742
Rollin

This Major Research Instrumentation Award supports Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University with the acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy and remote operational capability. The instrument will support research in nanomaterials characterization, along with development and characterization of emerging aerospace materials/structures that further improve safety, performance, fuel economy, longevity, and affordability. The SEM will have an impact on research and education at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. The institution recently launched several initiatives to upgrade its research programs at both the masters and PhD level, and the undergraduate level. The SEM will be integrated in current courses in the Colleges of Aviation, Engineering, and Arts and Sciences, and support new research areas at the undergraduate and graduate levels both on and off campus. It will also help attract and retain new research-oriented faculty to help develop the new PhD programs in Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Physics. The SEM will also be used in an existing outreach program to bring high-school teachers to visit the University during summers and conduct research projects with professors. Moreover, several local companies will also be using the SEM for their own research and development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to acquire a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) with Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDX) and remote operation capability. In December 2013, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University took delivery of an FEI Quanta 650 SEM with a Bruker Quantax 100 EDX. Remote operation capability was implemented for use across campus as well as from the outside. The SEM was first installed in March 2014 and full capability was reached in September 2014. This instrument added a basic capability to the University, allowing faculty and students to conduct fundamental materials science research. The SEM has been used in several Master’s theses as well as in several classes at the undergraduate and graduate level. Moreover, the SEM is strengthening the University’s collaboration with our industrial partners.

 

Intellectual Merit: The SEM has allowed faculty and students to conduct research. A few projects for which the SEM has been used: (1) Investigation of traditional and alternate living hinge designs for fused deposition modeling additive manufacturing process (graduate student thesis); (2) Development, analysis and comparison of electromechanical properties and electrode morphology of Ionic Polymer Metal Composites (graduate student thesis); (3) Effect of catalyst on the physical parameters of carbon spheres (graduate student thesis); (4) Growth and analysis of Carbon Nanotubes (undergraduate research project).

 

Broader Impact: The SEM was introduced to undergraduate and graduate students in several classes (1 undergraduate and 2 graduate classes). With the remote capability now functional, more students can be introduced to the wonders of the microscopic world by staying in their own classroom. Moreover, the SEM is now featured during our open house events to introduce future students and their families to the capability. Finally, local industries can use our microscope to solve their problems. They can use it on site with or without the help of one of our staff, or remotely. The final goal of the project is to introduce high school students to microscopy through their teachers. The team is currently working on implementing a summer school for teachers to learn about the microscope.
